awd_titl_txt: A Study of the Social, Ethical, and Policy Implications of Neuropsychological Research on Implicit Bias
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

A post-doctoral research fellow will examine the social, ethical, and policy implications of neuropsychological research on implicit bias. He will use a multi-sited qualitative methodology to empirically trace and elucidate the material consequences and social implications of implicit bias research. This project seeks to understand how neuroscience research on implicit bias is produced and organized in the lab, and to understand how social dynamics are conceptualized and operationalized in neuropsychological research on implicit bias, with specific emphasis on the promises and challenges of operationalizing race and racism at the neurobiological level. These determinations will then be used by the research fellow to elucidate the current and future interventions and policy opportunities for neuropsychological research on implicit bias. The results from this project will help better appraise ethical issues raised by the use of neuroscience research in society, which will aid in development and implementation of institutional and social policies on inequality and discrimination. The project serves enhance the number of underrepresented minority researchers focused on ethical, legal, and social impacts of science and technology.

Technical Summary 

This project is one of the first empirical science projects to examine how race is used and invoked in neuroscience research. It will contribute substantially to the well established Science, Technology, and Society (STS) research on genomics and race by providing insight into the ways these new neuro-understandings of cognition and behavior impact experiences with and practices of race. The study will address the growing use of bio-social models of research by focusing on the way social dynamics are measured and utilized in implicit bias research. The study will take the materiality and social realities of the brain seriously; in so doing, it will describe how the "social" is defined, operationalized, and transformed (or re-imagined) through neuro-research. In addition, the project will help illuminate the ethical challenges for neuroscience research and elucidate the advantages and limits of interdisciplinary STS scholarship that is focused on the intersections between the brain and sociality.

por.por_cntn:
This qualitative sociological project sought to help evaluate the social, ethical, and policy implications of neuroscience research on implicit bias. Implicit bias refers to unconscious thoughts or beliefs that are said to manifest in subtle prejudicial behaviors and attitudes toward particular social groups or stigmatized individuals. Recently, neuroscientists interested in the implicit bias have turned to novel imaging technologies to help trace a) how individuals recognize the racial identity of others, and b) how the brain helps determine and regulate bias thoughts that operate unconsciously.

Although, academics have explored the ethical and social impacts of genomics and race, there are very few empirical studies of the use of race in neuroscience research. This research set out to help address this gap. The project aimed to (1) understand how neuroscientist develop approaches to implicit bias; (2) describe how they measure and incorporate social variables (e.g., race and racism) in this research; and (3) outline policy interventions and opportunities related to neuroscience research on implicit bias.

The COVID epidemic limited my engagement with neuroscientists within their labs at different stages of this project. However, I was able to distill some significant findings regarding aim #2. These findings speak directly to the goal of improving future science and technology studies (STS) that analyze how race, racism, and other forms of social difference influence the making and practice of neuroscience. I discovered that social impacts of race are rarely talked about or used in neuropsychological research, beyond the explicit focus in neuroscience of implicit racial bias. Unlike studies about genomics and race, I found that neuroscientists working on implicit racial bias define and work with race as a social construct ? as a social product that has important impacts on the way the brain develops and functions in our everyday social engagements. Moreover, there is also some evidence that neuroscientists studying implicit racial bias often face unique intradisciplinary hurdles, in terms of gaining intellectual interest, funding, and/or respect from their neuroscientific colleagues.

Nevertheless, it remains unclear how these neuroscientists plan to translate neuroscientific findings about the brain and implicit bias into new policies and procedures that will productively combat systemic racism. More research is needed to help assess whether the public?s understanding of this science strengthens illogical links between race and biology. That is, whether the public sees this science as proof of race and racism as (neuro)biological, or brain hard-wired, products. Ongoing evidence from this study does suggests that the international attention to systemic racism following the events of the Summer of 2020, have led to new investments in diversity, equity, and inclusion programs and anti-racist agendas by neuroscientific funders, publishing groups, and academic institutions. This may open up greater discussions, beyond neuroscience, about the continued influence of scientific knowledge on the reproduction of racial discrimination and racisms in society, and potentially new ways that science can help combat these consequences.

Broader impacts from this study included interdisciplinary collaborations between neuroscience and sociology/STS. Collaborative opportunities between the PI and neuroscientists during this project led to co-authored academic articles. The PI was also invited to appear on neuroscientific panels that covered topics such as neuro-racism and keynote addresses at major neuroscientific events, such as NIH Brain Initiative Annual Conference. I was also invited for visits/talks at several neuroscience-related academic institutions, and importantly accepted invited guest lectures for neurobiological courses across the country. I developed two new courses based off the research from this project, which helped increased the number of science majors in my sociology classes. The courses, offered to both undergraduate and graduate students, are designed to help students evaluate the various ways that racial difference is made, maintained, or challenged through contemporary scientific practices. These courses are also designed to help students develop the skills to generate their own anti-racist science framework to embedded within their future development and use of science, knowledge, and technology.  

Finally, findings from this study suggest that STS scholars must rethink how scientific racism is often conceptualized (often as a purposeful practice or goal of science) to understanding how systemic racism is currently addressed, and the way it operates normatively in the biomedical sciences. A developing theoretical approach from this project seeks to understand how omission as a practice of dealing with scientific uncertainty may be one of biggest drivers of scientific racism. Such assessment is needed to fully evaluate and design how best to use, or not, neuroscientific data on implicit bias in social or institutional policy, and how to better train and teach future neuroscientific scholars.
